Graphical abstract The accumulation of polyolefin plastic wastes has emerged as a pressing global environmental challenge, driven by its inherent resistance to degradation and the limited efficiency of current recycling technologies. Hydroconversion methods, such as hydrocracking, offer a promising route for transforming polyolefins into high-value liquid alkanes under mild conditions. However, most current catalytic systems are heavily dependent on expensive noble metals, resulting in high management costs. Here, we report a cost-effective and scalable free of supported metals dual-catalyst system combining β zeolite and metal oxides (Nb2O5, CeO2, TiO2, or ZrO2) for the tandem cracking-hydrogenation of polyolefins under mild conditions. The system exploits a strong synergistic effect between β zeolite and oxide, achieving a polyethylene (PE) conversion of up to 98.2 % and liquid alkane yields of 87.1 %, with a product distribution centered in the C4–C15 range. Mechanistic investigations, supported by in situ spectroscopy and DFT calculations, revealed that polymer chains are initially cracked at the Brønsted acid sites of β zeolite to form olefins, which are subsequently hydrogenated on oxides via heterolytic H2 activation. Notably, the system demonstrated stability and versatility in processing PE-rich waste plastics. This study presents a practical and economically viable approach to converting plastic waste into valuable fuels, which is expected to advance sustainable chemical recycling strategies. Keywords Polyethylene upcycling Tandem catalysis Dual catalyst Zeolite and oxide synergy Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In recent years, the accumulation of plastic solid waste has exerted significant pressure on the environment worldwide [1–3]. In particular, the massive production of commodity polyolefins, which are characterized by low unit value and widespread use in short-term applications [4,5]. The molecular structure of polyolefins, with its high bond energy and chemical inertness, leads to an exceptionally slow degradation rate in the natural environment [6,7]. These factors collectively pose a severe and urgent waste management challenge. Currently, only a small fraction of polyolefins undergoes mechanical recycling, while the majority are either incinerated, landfilled, or released into the environment [8,9]. In contrast, the chemical recycling of polyolefin waste to produce high-value liquid fuels offers a more attractive approach to promoting responsible end-of-life management. Hydroconversion of polyolefins, including hydrocracking and hydrogenolysis, can cleave C–C bonds at lower temperatures (<300 °C), converting polyolefins into short-chain alkanes (Fig. 1 a) [10–13]. In contrast to pyrolysis (450 °C–900 °C), this process offers the advantage of milder reaction conditions [14–16]. Currently, the hotspot of polyolefin hydroconversion has primarily been on the development of metal–acid bifunctional catalysts [17–20]. Specifically, zeolites are commonly used as Brønsted acidic supports and have been widely applied in various hydrocracking studies, including ZSM-5, β, HY, and MOR [21–23]. In the case of metal-involved, noble metals (Pt, Ru, Rh, etc.) are widely used in hydrocracking, with Pt-based catalysts dominating [24–26]. And the transition metals (Co, Ni) generally exhibit lower reactivity (Fig. 1a) [27,28]. Although polyolefin hydroconversion holds great potential in selectively producing high-value liquid alkane fuels and reducing energy consumption, several critical issues remain unresolved. First, known low-temperature hydroconversion catalysts typically involve noble metals, resulting in high costs. Secondly, the use of noble metals, particularly Ru, often leads to the selective generation of low-value methane due to the rapid cleavage of terminal C–C bonds. Furthermore, while some transition metals catalysts can convert polyolefins, the conditions are relatively harsh and the reaction rate is slow. Recently, several innovative methods have emerged to depolymerize polyolefins under mild conditions using metal-free catalysts [29–31]. Huang et al. designed a structure consisting of ultra-small amorphous ZrO2 nanoparticles sandwiched between mesoporous silica layers [29]. Polymer chains migrate radially through radial mesopores to the highly active zirconia particles, where selective hydrogenolysis occurs, producing products centered around C18. The C–H bond heterolysis across a Zr–O bond of a Zr(O)2 adatom model for unsaturated surface sites gives a zirconium hydrocarbyl, which cleaves a C–C bond via β-alkyl elimination. Wu et al. reported a one-pot catalytic conversion method for PE to C4–C13 alkanes over SO4/ZrO2–Al2O3 catalyst [30]. Zhang et al. utilized the ionic liquid [C4Py]Cl–AlCl3 to convert PE into high value-added liquid iso-alkanes at 70 °C [31]. However, these advanced strategies heavily rely on catalysts with complex preparation steps, air-sensitive organometallic complexes, or intricate processing conditions. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop economically viable and high-performance free of supported metal catalysts to efficiently activate and depolymerize waste plastics. Here, we propose a cost-effective, easily available and scalable dual-catalyst system (Fig. 1b) that composed of oxides and zeolites for one-pot cracking-hydrogenation tandem reaction of polyethylene (PE). During the catalytic reaction, a strong synergy between zeolite and oxide components for acid-catalyzed cracking and hydrogenation is elucidated. The dual-catalyst system first activates, cracks, and isomerizes the PE chains over β zeolite to form olefins, which are subsequently hydrogenated on oxides via heterolytic H2 activation. A range of metal oxides, including Nb2O5, CeO2, TiO2, and ZrO2, when combined with β zeolite, exhibit high reactivity, with liquid alkane production up to 87.1 %, mainly in the C4–C15 range. In situ FTIR spectroscopy studies reveal the activation and cracking mechanisms of PE over the Brønsted acid sites of β zeolite. DFT calculations and in situ DRIFTS spectroscopy provide insights into the activation modes of H2 on metal oxides and the origin of hydrogenation capabilities on oxides. Obviously, this catalyst operates under conventional conditions and offers a competitive, cost-effective alternative to both noble metals and transition metals catalysts for the depolymerization of polyolefins. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials LDPE was purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. β zeolites with Si/Al ratios of 25 was supplied by Tianjin Nanhua Catalyst Ltd. Pure oxides, including Nb2O5, CeO2, TiO2, ZrO2 and SiO2, were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. All commercial catalysts were used directly after purchase without further treatment. 2.2 Characterization The structure of the catalysts was detected by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM 2100), scanning electron microscopy (SEM, SU8010). The X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected at a Bruker D8 advance powder diffractometer using a copper target (Cu Kα). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopic analysis was conducted by using pressed KBr disk in the region of 4000–400 cm−1. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was obtained with TGA55 instrument in air at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. 2.3 LDPE cracking-hydrogenation tandem reaction performance evaluation The catalytic performance of LDPE was evaluated in a 50 mL high-pressure reactor. Specifically, the catalyst and LDPE were thoroughly mixed physically in the reactor, which was then sealed. The reactor was purged with N2 three times to remove residual air. Subsequently, H2 was introduced to the desired pressure, and the temperature was raised to the target value to initiate the reaction. Upon completion of the reaction, gaseous products were collected from the headspace and analyzed using gas chromatography with flame ionization detection (GC-FID) equipped with an SH-Alumina BOND/Na2SO4 column. The mixture of liquid and solid products was weighed. Liquid products were extracted using CH2Cl2 as the extraction solvent, filtered to separate the liquid phase, and analyzed using GC with an MXT-1 column. All the Standards are purchased. For liquid products, the n-alkane standards (C5–C16, chromatographic grade) used to calibrate retention times were purchased from Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. For gas products, the n-alkane standards (C1–C4, 99.9 % purity) were purchased from Ludong Gas Co., Ltd. The response factors and retention times of hydrocarbons with different carbon numbers were calibrated using standard n-alkanes. The conversion rate was calculated using the following equation: C o n v e r s i o n = 1 - Mass of residual LDPE Initial mass of LDPE × 100% Quantification of the hydrocarbon C i was determined from the GC signal using external standard (n-hexadecane) reference: Y i e l d C i , % = Mass of C i Initial mass of LDPE × 100% = ( ∑ A r e a C i A r e a e x t e r n a l s t a n d a r d × Massofexternalstandard InitialmassofLDPE ) × 100 % where ∑ Area C i is the sum of GC areas of C i , Area (external standard) is the GC area of the external standard. The PE disappearance rate was defined on the basis of disappearance of PE, with the equation formulated as follows: P E d i s a p p e a r a n c e r a t e ( h - 1 ) = PEmass × P E c o n v e r s i o n catalystmass × r e a c t i o n t i m e 2.4 In situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) of PE tandem catalysis The rigid support for LDPE and catalyst was a KBr wafer, prepared by compressing 100 mg of KBr powder under a pressure of 20 MPa. Subsequently, layers of the catalyst and LDPE were sequentially coated onto the surface of the wafer. The catalyst was dispersed in ethanol at a concentration of 1 mg mL−1, and 1 mL of the suspension was dropped onto the KBr wafer. After the ethanol evaporated, the catalyst was deposited on the KBr surface. LDPE was dissolved in toluene at a concentration of 5 mg mL−1 at 100 °C, and 1 mL of the LDPE solution was slowly dropped onto the catalyst layer. After the toluene evaporated, a thin film ensuring close contact between the LDPE and the catalyst was obtained. The sample wafer was then placed in a high-temperature in-situ cell and pretreated at 100 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere for 1 h. In situ FTIR studies were performed using a Bruker II FTIR spectrometer. The spectra were recorded over a range of 850 cm−1 to 4000 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1. 2.5 In situ Diffuse Reflectance FTIR spectroscopy (DRIFTS) of pentene hydrogenation In situ DRIFTS spectra for 1-pentene hydrogenation were acquired using a Bruker Tensor II spectrometer. Prior to analysis, metal oxide underwent pretreatment at 150°C for 1 h under flowing N2 (30 mL min−1). A pentene/N2 gas mixture (total flow: 30 mL min−1; 1-pentene/N2 volumetric ratio = 1:9) was introduced under 240 °C until saturation adsorption. The system was subsequently purged with pure N2 flow (30 mL min−1) under 240 °C to desorb physiosorbed molecules, thereby ensuring retention of strongly chemisorbed species on the catalyst surface. The reaction was initiated by introducing a H2/N2 mixture (total flow: 30 mL min−1; H2/N2 volumetric ratio = 1:9) into the IR cell, with spectral acquisition commencing simultaneously with reaction initiation. DRIFTS spectra were recorded at 1 min intervals throughout the reaction. 2.6 In situ DRIFTS of H2 activation In situ DRIFTS spectra for H2 activation were acquired using a Bruker Tensor II spectrometer. Prior to analysis, catalysts underwent pretreatment at 150 °C for 1 h under flowing N2 (30 mL min−1), followed by cooling to ambient temperature. Subsequently, the gas flow was switched to a H2/N2 mixture (total flow: 30 mL min−1; H2/N2 volumetric ratio = 1:9), while the temperature was ramped from ambient to 300 °C at a rate of 5 °C min−1. Spectra were recorded at 10 °C intervals throughout the heating process. 2.7 DFT calculation details All theoretical analyses are based on Density Functional Theory (DFT). The crystal planes of the various oxides selected for the DFT calculations were determined based on the main crystal planes obtained from XRD. The general gradient-corrected (GGA) with Perdew-Burke-Erzerhof (PBE) functional is utilized to describe the electron exchange–correlation potential. The electrons are described by DFT Semi-core Pseudopots (DSPP) basis set and a double numerical plus polarization (DNP). The vacuum slab is set as 20 Å to avoid the interaction of periodic images. The real atomic space cutoff radius is 4.5 Å. The kohn–sham self-consistent field calculations are performed with convergency tolerance of 1 × 10–6 Ha on the total energy. A thermal smearing (0.005 Ha) is applied to the orbital occupation to speed up convergence during geometry optimization. In addition, the complete Linear Synchronous Transit and Quadratic Synchronous Transit (LST/QST) method was employed to find the transition state (TS). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Cracking-hydrogenation tandem reaction performance of polyolefins The catalytic performance of polyolefins over the catalysts was evaluated in a high-pressure reactor, and structural details of the catalysts provided in Fig. S4–S10. For performance evaluation, a mixture of low-density polyethylene (LDPE) and the catalyst was heated under a hydrogen atmosphere at 240 °C for 2 h (Fig. 2 a–d). Under these conditions, β zeolite exhibited limited catalytic activity, achieving only a 30.0 % conversion rate and yielding 25.1 % alkanes in the C4–C15 range (Table 1 , entry 1). These results showed the potential of β zeolite as a shape-selective and nano-scale catalyst for selective conversion of PE into products with a concentrated distribution. Similarly, metal oxide alone, including Nb2O5, CeO2, TiO2, and ZrO2, displayed negligible activity under identical reaction conditions, with conversion rates below 10 % (Fig. 2a and Table 1, entry 2–5). These findings indicate that neither β zeolite alone nor the oxides individually can effectively overcome the kinetic barriers inherent in the tandem catalysis of plastics. Remarkably, the simple mechanical mixing of β zeolite with oxides resulted in a significant enhancement in catalytic performance (Fig. 2a and Table 1, entry 7–10). Among these dual-catalysts, the β + Nb2O5 demonstrated the best performance, achieving a LDPE conversion of 98.2 % and yielding 87.1 % alkanes in the C4–C15 range (Table 1, entry 7). As summarized in Table S2, the gas product yields for β + oxide tandem catalytic systems ranged from 6.7 to 7.7 %, underscoring the negligible contribution of gaseous hydrocarbons to overall product distribution. Notably, C4 alkanes constituted about 50 % of total gaseous products. Normalization of the PE disappearance rate calibrated to the mass of the metal oxide catalysts. As illustrated in Fig. 2d, the PE disappearance rates for β + Nb2O5 (2.43 h−1), β + CeO2 (2.35 h−1), β + TiO2 (2.28 h−1), and β + ZrO2 (2.05 h−1). Subsequently, the composition of the products was analyzed in detail. The alkane products were distributed in the range of C4–C15, centered around C7–C9 (Fig. 2b). The primary products were branched alkanes rather than linear alkanes (Table 1), attributed to the excellent isomerization capability of β zeolite. Branched alkanes, due to their higher octane numbers, are more advantageous than linear alkanes for use as fuels [32]. Furthermore, the dual-catalyst system produced negligible amounts of C1–C3 alkanes (Fig. 2c), supporting the dominance of the classical acid-catalyzed cracking mechanism. This mechanism involves β-scission of C–C bonds, and the formation of carbocations with C1–C3 is energetically unfavorable due to their high energy [33]. Using the β + Nb2O5 dual-catalyst, we further evaluated the effects of reaction time, temperature, and hydrogen pressure on catalytic performance (Fig. 2e and Fig. 3 a, b). Conversion increased with longer reaction times, higher temperatures, and elevated pressures. As summarized in Tables S3–S5, these parametric studies collectively demonstrate that β-zeolite controls cracking, while Nb2O5 governs hydrogenation depth. Time and temperature predominantly influence cracking severity, shifting products toward lighter/gaseous species through secondary reactions. Conversely, H2 pressure regulates saturation efficiency, suppressing olefins but risking over-cracking at extremes. This separation of functions explains the reason of high conversion with high liquid yield is achievable at “sweet-spot” conditions: 240 °C, 1.0 MPa H2, and 2 h reaction time. Next, we investigated the applicability of the dual-catalyst system across polyolefin waste plastics. Common PE-rich plastic waste from daily life, including PE bags, PE films, PE gloves, and PE bottles, was successfully converted into high-yield liquid products with a concentrated product distribution (Fig. 3c–f). The combination of stability and low-cost catalyst is crucial for reducing the cost of waste polyolefins chemical recycling. Consequently, we performed catalyst reusability experiments with the β + Nb2O5 dual-catalyst system. After three reaction cycles, the conversion remained at 90.7 %, showing only a 7.5 % decrease compared to the fresh catalyst (Fig. S12 and Table 1, entry 11), demonstrating the reasonably stable performance of the catalytic system. As shown in Fig. S13, the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of the fresh and used β + Nb2O5 catalysts confirm retained microporosity. The surface area decreased slightly from 455 m2/g (fresh) to 424 m2/g (used), while the average pore size narrowed marginally from 0.45 nm to 0.41 nm after reaction, indicating that the catalyst structure remains largely intact, with no significant collapse or blockage of the zeolite framework. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the spent catalyst further revealed its outstanding resistance to coking (Fig. S14). 3.2 Investigation of catalytic mechanism 3.2.1 In situ FTIR spectroscopy of cracking-hydrogenation tandem reaction To gain atomic-level insights into the reaction mechanism, in situ FTIR spectroscopy was employed to investigate polyethylene conversion over β zeolite, Nb2O5, and β + Nb2O5 dual-catalyst system. On Nb2O5, the IR spectrum of polyethylene exhibits three peaks at 2920, 2855, and 1463 cm−1, assigned to the asymmetric C–H stretching vibration, symmetric C–H stretching vibration, and C–H bending vibration of methylene groups (–CH2–), respectively (Fig. 4 a) [34,35]. During the constant temperature period, the persistence of these methylene vibrational features indicates the inherent difficulty in the polyethylene conversion solely over Nb2O5. Further investigation focused on the polyethylene deconstruction process over β zeolite (Fig. 4b). As reaction time progressed, a peak emerged at 3468 cm−1, characteristic of hydrogen bond between carbon chain and the Brønsted acid sites, indicating activation of polyethylene via Brønsted acid sites in β zeolite. The peak of methylene groups at 2920 cm−1 underwent a blue shift to 2930 cm−1, confirming the strong interaction between the polyethylene methylene groups and the acid sites of β zeolite. The intensity of the methylene bands (2920, 2855, 1463 cm−1) declined over time, while the peak corresponding to methyl groups (1382 cm−1) enhanced significantly. This evolution specifically demonstrates the capability of β zeolite to cleave polyethylene chains, yielding lighter hydrocarbon. After 1 h of reaction, new unsaturated species (manifested by a CC bond stretching band at 1620 cm−1) gradually accumulated on the catalyst surface, signifying the generation of olefinic intermediates upon cleavage of the long polyethylene chains. Additionally, the absence of peaks of aromatic compounds (at 3105 cm−1 and 1506 cm−1) was observed throughout the reaction. The dual-catalyst system comprising β and Nb2O5 exhibited a synergistic catalytic effect during polyethylene conversion (Fig. 4c). While significant accumulation of olefinic intermediates (CC bond at 1620 cm−1) was evident on pure β zeolite after 5 h of reaction, these intermediates were rapidly consumed over the dual catalyst system in the presence of Nb2O5, underscoring the indispensable role of Nb2O5 in facilitating the conversion of CC intermediates (Fig. S15). These observations collectively suggest a sequential transformation of polyethylene: initially, polyethylene adsorbs onto the Brønsted acid sites of β zeolite via hydrogen-bonding interactions; subsequently, it undergoes cleavage to form olefinic intermediates; finally, these intermediates undergo complete hydrogenation to alkane products catalyzed by the metal oxide sites. This promotion of hydrogenation drives a tandem catalytic process, facilitating final product formation by shifting the chemical equilibrium. 3.2.2 Mechanism investigation of the activation of dihydrogen over metal oxides Further, the mechanism of the subsequent hydrogenation of olefin intermediates produced by cracking on oxides was studied. As we all know, the ability to activate molecular dihydrogen is a prerequisite for efficient hydrogenation. Consequently, in situ DRIFTS spectroscopy was employed to study the activation mode of H2 on oxide surfaces (Fig. 5 ). As depicted in Fig. 5a–d, upon heating in a hydrogen atmosphere from room temperature to 300 °C, a series of IR peaks emerged, corresponding to the activation of hydrogen. Specifically, peaks in the 3000–3500 cm−1 range were attributed to the vibrations of co-adsorption of water molecules and newly formed OH groups on the oxide surface. Simultaneously, signals corresponding to M−H species (M = Nb, Ce, Ti, Zr) were also detected, serving as direct evidence of the heterolytic cleavage of H2 [36–40]. Temperature was found to play a critical role in the activation of H2 on oxides. At lower temperatures, no OH or M−H species were observed. However, as the temperature increased from 200 °C to 300 °C, the intensity of the activation signals intensified, indicating enhanced H2 dissociation. Furthermore, time-dependent experiments (Figs. S17–S20) conducted at the reaction temperature (240 °C) demonstrate unambiguous OH and M−H (Nb–H: ∼1650 cm−1, Ti–H: ∼2900 cm−1, Ce–H: ∼1050 cm−1 and Zr–H: ∼1600 cm−1) peaks attributable to heterolytic dissociation of H2. These signatures exhibited progressive intensification over 15–25 min of H2 exposure. Taking the DRIFTS spectra of H2 dissociation on Nb2O5 as an example (Fig. S17a), the peaks at 3600–3400 cm−1 and 3400–3200 cm−1 are attributed to O–H free and O–H chelate stretching vibrations modes, respectively. the peak at ∼ 1650 cm−1 corresponds unambiguously to Nb–H stretching vibrations. Critically, the concurrent enhancement in peak intensities of O–H and M−H vibrations over time arises from the heterolytic dissociation of H2, wherein active hydrogen species bond to metal atoms or oxygen atoms, providing direct evidence for heterolytic H2 activation. In addition, the O–H bonds in the 3800–3200 cm−1 region are characteristic of water molecules Therefore, the O–H bands observed should be attributed to the co-adsorption of water molecules and active hydrogen species derived from H2 dissociation. To elucidate the dihydrogen activation mechanism on metal oxide surfaces, in situ DRIFTS spectroscopy was employed to investigate D2 exposure on Nb2O5. As shown in Fig. S17b, the peaks emerge at 2550 cm−1 and 3640–3250 cm−1 upon D2 introduction, assigned to O–D free and O–D chelate stretching vibrations, respectively. Concurrently, the peak appears in the 1520–1430 cm−1 region corresponding to Nb–D vibrations. These observations constitute additional evidence for dihydrogen activation. Furthermore, the consumption of free O–H groups occurs due to H–D exchange between active D-species and metal oxide surface hydroxyl groups. DFT calculations provided deeper insights into the formation of active hydrogen species on the oxide surface [36,41–44]. As illustrated in Fig. 5e and f, the heterolytic dissociation pathway was determined to be kinetically and energetically more favorable than the homolytic pathway. For instance, on Nb2O5, the energy barrier for heterolytic dissociation (0.88 eV) was significantly lower than that for homolytic dissociation (2.75 eV). These results elucidate the activation pathway of H2: molecular dihydrogen adsorbs onto the oxide surface and undergoes heterolytic dissociation into a proton and a hydride ion. The proton associates with surface oxygen atoms to form OH groups, while the hydride ion binds to metal atoms, generating M−H species. The combined experimental observations and computational analysis confirm the ability of oxides to activate and dissociate H2 effectively. And, the formation of active hydrogen species provides essential mechanistic insights into the catalytic functionality of oxides. 3.2.3 Mechanism investigation of hydrogenation over metal oxides To elucidate the hydrogenation mechanism of olefins on metal oxides, pentene was employed as a probe molecule (Fig. 6 a). Initially, the adsorption capabilities of oxides (Nb2O5, CeO2, TiO2, and ZrO2) toward olefin were examined. In situ DRIFTS spectra were collected under a nitrogen atmosphere at 240 °C, with adsorption saturating on the oxide surfaces within 30 min. Signal peaks corresponding to the adsorption of the CC bond (1625 cm−1) and the C–H bonds (2960 and 1457 cm−1) were observed (Fig. 6a) [45–47]. The adsorption strength of the substrates followed the trend: Nb2O5 > CeO2 > ZrO2 > TiO2 (Fig. 6b). Subsequently, after removing physically adsorbed molecules, hydrogen gas was introduced, and the hydrogenation behavior on the oxides was monitored in situ under reaction conditions (Fig. 6a). Within 2 min, the intensity of the CC vibration band diminished rapidly, accompanied by a concurrent decrease in the C–H vibration bands, dynamically verifying the hydrogenation of olefins to alkanes. Unfortunately, the vibrational signals of alkane products were not detected, likely due to the rapid desorption of products from the catalyst surface at high temperatures. After normalizing the signal intensities, the hydrogenation rates were quantified, following the same trend observed for adsorption capacity: Nb2O5 > CeO2 > ZrO2 > TiO2 (Fig. 6c). The microscopic reaction rates corresponded well with the macroscopic catalytic performance. Notably, Nb2O5 exhibited the most pronounced hydrogenation effect, achieving nearly complete conversion of the CC bonds within just 4 min. Control experiments under pure N2 flow at 240 °C showed no CC signal reduction over 15 min (Fig. S21). These measures clearly define hydrogenation as the sole contributor to peak attenuation. 3.2.4 DFT calculations As previously discussed, the widely accepted mechanism for olefin hydrogenation involves the dissociative chemisorption of H2 and the adsorption of substrate. Using DFT calculations, we explored possible reaction pathways for olefin hydrogenation on various oxide surfaces, including the co-adsorption of 2H atoms and substrate, followed by the hydrogenation of substrate. The calculated adsorption energies (Fig. 7 a, b), which serve as a proxy for adsorption rates, followed the trend: Nb2O5 (1.94 eV) > CeO2 (1.26 eV) > ZrO2 (1.16 eV) > TiO2 (0.58 eV). These values confirm that olefins can adsorb on all four oxide surfaces, with Nb2O5 showing the most robust adsorption energy, a favorable characteristic for catalytic performance. Next, the energetics of the CC bond hydrogenation steps were evaluated using Nb2O5 and CeO2 as representative examples. On Nb2O5, the first hydrogenation step (converting *C5H10 and *H to *C5H11) requires overcoming an energy barrier of only 0.18 eV, while the second hydrogenation step (converting *C5H11 and *H to *C5H12) has a barrier of 0.92 eV (Figs. 7c and S22). In comparison, these steps on CeO2 exhibit significantly higher barriers of 0.73 eV and 1.51 eV, respectively (Figs. 7c and S23). Therefore, for both Nb2O5 and CeO2, the rate-determining step is the second hydrogenation steps in the CC bond hydrogenation. Moreover, the consistently lower hydrogenation barriers on Nb2O5 compared to CeO2 indicate that the reaction is thermodynamically more favorable on Nb2O5, facilitating easier conversion of olefins to alkanes. To elucidate the promoting effect of oxides on the conversion rate in a tandem catalytic system, the PE disappearance rate was re-normalized to the quantity of Lewis acid sites present on the oxide catalysts. Quantitative assessment of acid site densities was conducted via pyridine-adsorbed FTIR spectroscopy (Fig. S24). As shown in Fig. S25, the PE disappearance rates for β + Nb2O5, β + TiO2, β + CeO2, and β + ZrO2 catalysts were quantified as 242, 134, 88, and 53 g mmol-1h−1, exhibiting the crucial role of Nb2O5-derived Lewis acid sites in governing the PE cracking-hydrogenation tandem reaction. We believe that the strong Lewis acidity of pentacoordinated Nb5+ sites on Nb2O5 effectively polarizes the CC bonds of olefin intermediates. This accelerated hydrogenation kinetically promotes the tandem catalytic process by favorably altering the chemical equilibrium. We have constructed a complete reaction pathway for tandem cracking-hydrogenation of polyolefins facilitated by the dual-catalyst system (Fig. 7d). The process begins with the adsorption of polymer chains onto the Brønsted acid sites of β zeolite. The microporous structure of the zeolite selectively facilitates β-scission and isomerization, producing olefins predominantly in the range of C4–C15. Simultaneously, H2 is activated on the metal oxide surface through a heterolytic cleavage mechanism, generating active hydrogen species. These olefins are adsorbed onto the metal oxide surface, where they undergo hydrogenation via interaction with dissociated active hydrogen species, yielding alkanes. Finally, the alkanes desorb from the catalyst surface, regenerating the catalytic sites and completing the catalytic cycle. 4 Conclusion The development of efficient and cost-effective catalytic methods for converting plastic waste into valuable alkane fuels represents a critical area of research. This study developed a cost-effective, easily available and scalable dual-catalyst system combining zeolites and oxides. This dual-catalyst system demonstrates efficient performance, effectively producing high-value alkanes in the C4–C15 range. β zeolite, with its abundant strong Brønsted acid sites, exhibits reactivity in cracking, while its microporous structure facilitates selective β-scission and isomerization, enabling a narrow product distribution. The metal oxide component plays two pivotal roles in the reaction: heterolytically activating H2 and adsorbing CC bonds to complete the hydrogenation process. The strong synergies between the zeolites and metal oxides dual-catalyst promotes targeted cleavage of C–C bonds in polyolefins. Owing to its efficiency, stability, and cost-effectiveness, this dual-catalyst system holds significant potential for catalytic upcycling of polyolefin waste in practical applications. coredata.dc:description: The accumulation of polyolefin plastic wastes has emerged as a pressing global environmental challenge, driven by its inherent resistance to degradation and the limited efficiency of current recycling technologies. Hydroconversion methods, such as hydrocracking, offer a promising route for transforming polyolefins into high-value liquid alkanes under mild conditions. However, most current catalytic systems are heavily dependent on expensive noble metals, resulting in high management costs. Here, we report a cost-effective and scalable free of supported metals dual-catalyst system combining β zeolite and metal oxides (Nb2O5, CeO2, TiO2, or ZrO2) for the tandem cracking-hydrogenation of polyolefins under mild conditions. The system exploits a strong synergistic effect between β zeolite and oxide, achieving a polyethylene (PE) conversion of up to 98.2 % and liquid alkane yields of 87.1 %, with a product distribution centered in the C4–C15 range. Mechanistic investigations, supported by in situ spectroscopy and DFT calculations, revealed that polymer chains are initially cracked at the Brønsted acid sites of β zeolite to form olefins, which are subsequently hydrogenated on oxides via heterolytic H2 activation. Notably, the system demonstrated stability and versatility in processing PE-rich waste plastics. This study presents a practical and economically viable approach to converting plastic waste into valuable fuels, which is expected to advance sustainable chemical recycling strategies.
